Posts.Content: shadow38 wrote: Hey All, I just returned from my appointment with my bs and things have gotten even more complicated and I'm more confused and frightened than ever.  I have another suspicious area in the same breast as the cancer.  The cancer is in the 8-9 o'clock position.  This nodule is in the 4-5 o'clock position, so it's opposite the area of diagnosed carcinoma. The MRI identified it as a "Suspected 10mm fibroadenoma" and states it is "a well marginated nodule.  It demonstrates persistent contrast enhancement and does contain central regions of decreased signal intensity.  This is felt to likely represent a fibroadenoma.  A focused right breast sonogram is recommended for further evaluation."  The bs himself noted the following on the report:  "apparent benign lesion at 4:00". HOWEVER, it's the focused sonogram (which I had yesterday) results that are freaking me out.  The sonogram results read:  "A well marginated, oval shaped, hypoechoic nodule with a maximum diameter of approx 9mm was noted....The long axis of this nodule is parallel to the skin surface.  This also demonstrates a sharp posterior wall and posterior acoustic enhancement.  This does contain a central linear region of increased echogenicity.  The sonographic appearance of this nodule is suggestive of an intramammary lymph node with a thickened cortical mantle.  As the patient does have carcinoma with the right breast, this is SUSPICIOUS FOR AN INTRAMAMMARY NODAL METASTASIS.  If clinically indicated, a sonographically guided biopsy of the nodule may be performed for further evaluation."  I did an internet search for "Intramammary Nodal Metastasis" and found only 2 articles, both of which indicated that this was a precursor to decreased survival and further lymph node involvement in the axillary region.  As you can imagine, I'm going crazy here.  I also searched this site and found nothing.  The bs is saying that IF this nodule is benign, he will recommend lumpectomy.  IF it's found to be malignant, he will recommend a mastectomy of the right breast.  HELP !!!!!!!!!  Does anyone have any experience with this??  Dx 3/10/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: The Hits Keep On Coming....HELP! shadow38 Tabbygirl521

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 12:12PM shadow38 wrote: Thank you so much, Angela!! That's not false hope!!  It's 3 medically educated people who do this everyday "not sounding dreadfully concerned".  That means alot!!  Doctors don't just randomly say things.  They say what they say from experience.  I'M VERY, VERY ENCOURAGED and I will be praying for you! It's a wet, cold day here in New York.  Enjoy the sun in your neck of the woods!  I'll be back later! Love, Kathy
Posts.Title: The Hits Keep On Coming....HELP! shadow38 Tabbygirl521

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 02:50PM shadow38 wrote: Just to let you guys know, I did see the bs yesterday and got even more good news.  I'm BRAC negative!!  Thank God!!  Hopefully, Angela, your test will be the same.  You have all my good thoughts!! After alot of research and careful consideration, I'm going with a Lumpectomy and SNB.  The risks of re-excision (and even Mastectomy) have been explained to me, but my bs feels I'm a good candidate for the surgery.  He still feels the actual tumor is small (the remains of the cystic sac is 2 cm) and is "probably not" in my nodes.  I've done a ton of research on reoccurence, etc.  I hope I'm making the right decision.  All you can do is weigh your options, do the research and move forward with what feels like the best choice.  The surgery is on April 13th.
Posts.Title: The Hits Keep On Coming....HELP! shadow38 Tabbygirl521

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 01:11PM shadow38 wrote: Hi Sue, Thank you for the information, encouragement,  and experience.  They help ALOT!  My first pathology report has already been reviewed by a second lab, so atleast I got that part right.  I haven't done a second opinion on the bs yet only because I feel comfortable with him and he was recommended by my internist whom I've been with for atleast 15 years.  He's associated with a major teaching hospital as is my oncologist so that was encouraging to me.  I think I may follow your advice though.  Its good to know that radiologists tend to be more conservative.  The MRI leaned heavily toward a benign fibroadenoma and normal fibrocystic change.  So did the bs.  Atleast I have something to hang onto until I get the report Wednesday or Thursday.  WOW!!  5 benign biopsies!!  How did you not go completely insane!?!?!?!  I'm so sorry you had to go through that!  Your advice about "abstracting yourself" from what's going on around you is excellent.  I'm trying.  I seem to be better able to accomplish it in the bs's office or during other appointments.  It's when I get home that my mind seems to run away with me.  I keep assuming the worst, possibly because of how I was diagnosed ("It's just a cyst" - until it wasn't) or possibly, and I'm loathe to admit this, because I have a negative attitude.  I come from a family of "the glass is half empty" thinkers and I always thought I was the family exception.  Maybe I'm not. Do you know that old saying "Tell me who you travel with and I'll tell you what you are"?  Perhaps I'm more like them than I ever realized.  I'm fortunate in that my amazing hubby is NOT a negative thinker and that has helped tremendously.  Neither are my friends, which also helps alot.  And of course there's this wonderful place with all the positive thinkers and strong people.  All that keeps me going. I'm sorry ANY OF US have to go through this.  I'm gaining strength through other experiences and the information everyone here provides.  That's so comforting.  If it's the last thing I do, I WILL pay that forward.  Thanks for everything! Kathy
Posts.Title: The Hits Keep On Coming....HELP! shadow38 Tabbygirl521

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 11:09AM shadow38 wrote: Just got a call from the bs's office.  The Intramammary Lymph Node is Benign.  Its not an ILN at all.  Its a Fibroadenoma!!  Thank God!!!!!!!!!!!  Finally!!  Some good news!!  I'm still waiting on the BRCA too, Angela, but this is encouraging enough to make me happy today.  Thanks for your crossed fingers.  They worked!! Sue.....Thanks for you good wishes and crossed fingers too!!  I'm headed to the bs in a little while.  My assumption is that we'll discuss the surgery.  I'll let you guys know what happens.  Love, Kathy
Posts.Title: The Hits Keep On Coming....HELP! shadow38 Tabbygirl521

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 01:50PM shadow38 wrote: Thank you so much Susan, barbe, Janet and Jacqueline for the additional information.  I can't tell you how much you guys and everyone else here has helped me.  I'm praying the nodule is benign.  As I said, the bs thinks the radiologist was "over reaching", but nothing would surprise me at this point.  I think I'm doing a little better.  I'm still terrified, but the whole shock and awe thing is wearing off a little.  I'm taking 1.0 mg of Xanax at night to sleep, but other than that, I'm getting through the days with a lot of help from family and friends.  I've had alot of discomfort on occasion in my neck, shoulder and shoulder blade on the opposite side of the cancer,  but I think it's just the stress of everything manifesting itself physically.  I think my muscles are strung as tight as piano wire!  It seems to be there on and off.  I guess stress can do alot to a body.  My only other problem has been with weight.  I lost a few pounds and its not coming back easily despite my trying to eat.  I guess that's a stress thing too.  A year ago I would have been thrilled to have that "problem".   I still don't even know if I'm going to need a lumpectomy (if the node is benign) or a mastectomy (if it isn't), let alone what type of cancer I have, the actual size of the tumor or the stage.  It's alot and as everyone of you know, your mind can go to all kinds of negative places.  This forum has been a life saver.  Reading the threads and seeing how well you guys handle things is a source of comfort.  I've learned so much in the past 2 weeks.  In the beginning, I was afraid to read certain threads.  Now.....it's all about how much I can learn from everyone else's experiences.  Maybe that means I'm getting stronger.  God, I hope so.  HUGS and Thanks to All
Posts.Title: The Hits Keep On Coming....HELP! shadow38 Tabbygirl521

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 12:57PM shadow38 wrote: Dear Angela, I'm so sorry you're going through this all again, but welcome to the site nobody wants to be a member of.  The people here are amazing!  If you have a question day or night, someone will pop on and talk to you.  The information on this site has been a lifeline for me.  The waiting really is horrible!  Unfortunately, since I've never had surgery, I had real issues with everything.  I'm starting to settle down a bit, but I still have my days where I assume the worst and cry alot.  My "suspicious" Intramammary Lymph Node is in the opposite quadrant of my breast.  It was biopsied on Tuesday and I see the BS tomorrow, so I guess I'll know what type of surgery I need at that time (lumpectomy if it's benign, mastectomy if it's not).  I also had the BRCA screening.  I understand that only 10% of the population actually have BRCA 1 or 2.  I'm hoping (obviously) that I'm in the 90%.  Extra caution is a good thing.  If we're going to kick BC's ass, information is power! As far as adding your dx to your profile, there's a section under your profile you can go to in order to add the information.  I think you go to "My Home" at the top of the page and that will lead you to where you need to go.  I'll be thinking about you as well Angela, and I'm sending you Hugs!!   We can do this! Kathy
Posts.Title: The Hits Keep On Coming....HELP! shadow38 Tabbygirl521

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 12:10PM shadow38 wrote: Like Deb, I was also told not to try to quit smoking during Chemo.  My Oncologist felt my stress level would be through the roof (she was right).  I've cut down and feel strong enough to give it try.  I'm almost halfway through treatment.  I also had no problem healing from my lumpectomy and SNB.  I actually healed very, very well.  Please understand....I'm not advocating smoking at all and I plan to quit this coming week using the Nicotine patch.  I tried to quit as soon as I was diagnosed (talk about trying to catch the horse AFTER it's left the barn), but I was literally freaking out and couldn't do it!!  I think the doctors weigh how long you've been smoking and your mental condition.  I'm a longtime smoker so I guess mine felt a few more weeks wouldn't matter. As far as the drinking is concerned, I was told "ABSOLUTELY NO ALCOHOL DURING CHEMO".  I'm not a drinker so it wasn't a problem for me.
Posts.Title: ALCOHOL / SMOKING - during chemo!!! HELP!!! TravisC bwbly

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2009 12:42PM - edited Sep 12, 2009 12:44PM by shadow38 I did, unklezwife.  I was told Neulasta was not an option with weekly Taxol because it's designed to be long lasting.  I took Neupogen for 3 days after each infusion (which lasted about an hour and a half after premeds).  I was able to do the Neupogen at home after they taught me to inject myself.  It wasn't bad.  I had no neuropathy.  I did have body and joint aches and felt as though every inch of my skin was bruised.  I was anemic (duh!) and I'm still a bit low.  The fatigue was killer for me.  My nails weakened and turned brown but I didn't lose them.  Also had mild abdominal pain 2 days after treatment but nothing I couldn't handle.  I'm now 6 weeks out and I feel pretty good.  A little tired, but almost back to normal! Good Luck!
Posts.Title: Taxol - How long does it take? Tabatha00 shadow38

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 03:23PM - edited Jun 8, 2009 03:28PM by shadow38 Hi Springtime: No....that's not it.  I wash my hair everyday when I take my shower.  It's just not coming out.  Also, on two separate occasions after the Carbo treatments, I've had tenderness of the scalp that I thought would be the beginning of the end for my hair, but alas.....it just goes away without my hair ever falling out.  It lasts a day or two and POOF, it's the discomfort is gone and my hair is still in my head.  It could be that I'm in that small percentage that doesn't lose their hair.  I dunno.  I've read on a couple of UK websites that some patients taking Taxol and Caboplatin keep their hair.  I guess we'll see eventually.  Hey nodapearl: I know EXACTLY what you're talking about.  I've only gained about 2 lbs since I started tx, but I have a pot belly which I've never had.  I lost alot of weight when I was diagnosed (didn't eat much for 3 weeks) and if anything, I'm scrawny, but the belly is definitely there.  It seems my weight has been redistributed!  Very strange.  I mentioned it to my Onc and she said it was due to the steriods.  I also have a ridiculous appetite.  I eat everything that isn't nailed down!!  I should have gained more weight, but as I said, it seems to be redistributed to my belly.  I have the muffin top from hell.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2009 01:43PM shadow38 wrote: I originally posted this in the T, C and H thread, but it was suggested that it might be better placed here!!  Can anyone offer any support or input?  I would really appreciate it!! --------------------------------------------------------------- I wonder if any of you can help me with something that's causing a great deal of anxiety for me, but probably sounds totally ridiculous to everyone else?  This is really freaking me out guys!!  I'm on 12 weekly doses of Taxol and Herceptin with a heavier dose of Carboplatin added in every third week.  I began treatment on May 6th and have completed 5 doses of T & H and 2 of T, C and H together.  Right now I'm at day 12 since my 2nd Carbo and 33 days into treatment.  This coming Wednesday I'll be halfway through treament.  I was told I would lose my hair within 21 days of my first treatment and I was prepared as anyone could be for something like that.  I bought my wig and headcovers and started waiting just like everyone else here.  Now here I am, 33 days after treatment began and not one hair has fallen out of my head and it's scaring the every lovin' crap out of me that the Chemo is NOT working.  If it can't even kill my hair cells, how the heck is it killing cancer cells!?!??!  I know with weekly Taxol and Herceptin (thanks to NanaA) that sometimes the hair just thins, but I was told with the Carbo I would "definately lose my hair within 3 weeks".  Each week I go in for treatment and the Chemo nurses and the Onc. are shocked by the fact that I haven't lost my hair.  They just shrug their shoulders and assure me it'll start happening "by next week", yet nothing happens.  I know this must sound like I'm looking a gift horse in the mouth, but this is scaring the heck out of me.  The anxiety of thinking that Chemo is not working is freaking me out.  I have had some other side effects including fatigue on days 3 & 4, severe heartburn, feeling as though my entire body is bruised (sore to the touch), but my blood counts are in the normal range (barely) and I haven't had to take the Neupogen shots that were prescribed for me 3 weeks ago.  I feel as if my body is resistant or something. I mentioned this to the doctor the week before last and she sort of blew me off saying the hair loss will absolutely happen!  Has anyone else either had this experience or heard of someone having an experience like this?  Please understand that I wouldn't ask unless it was causing this much anxiety, but it is.  I'm not looking forward to losing my hair, but the idea that the Chemo might not be working is really upsetting me!  HELP!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 02:57PM - edited Jun 7, 2009 02:59PM by shadow38 Thanks to everyone who responded with encouragement and information.  You have no idea how much it helps!!  Interestingly, I found a couple of UK websites that listed Carboplatin and Taxol as Chemo drugs that MIGHT NOT cause hair loss.  Lisa:  Please feel free to talk about me behind my back.  I absolutely deserve it.  The nerve of my stupid, arrogant hair!!   Yea....I definitely have the other side effects.  My blood must be pretty low this week.  I'm really light headed!  Usually I'm out of commission on day 3, tired but better on day 4 and completely fine by day 5.  Today is day 5 and I'm lightheaded and tired.  Believe it or not, that's actually encouraging to me!  I guess my blood counts are low.  Marybe:  I do have a really FULL head of hair, like you.  Always have.  Maybe that's it.  We just happen to have really good roots that hang in there longer than most!!  Also I tend to have a really strong immune system.  When everyone in the house would be down with a cold or something, for some odd reason, I'd manage to avoid it.  Who knows!  What I do know is hearing your story is encouraging.  I don't feel as alone and just plain weird. I've noticed on two different occasions (after each Carboplatin treatment) my scalp was very sore and tender.  Each time that feeling lasted a couple of days and then just went away.  Maybe I'm just not noticing the thinning because I have so much hair?  I guess it could be.  I also still have some hair on my arms, however the other hair on my body is not growing at all.  I shaved my legs and underarms a couple of weeks ago and still have nothing growing.  Too much information?  Definitely!  xpectamiracle:  Thank you so much for the encouragement and understanding.  I almost feel like a traitor for NOT losing my hair and I really am scared that the Chemo isn't doing it's thing.  I never thought I would say this, but THANK GOD for the other side effects.  Sounds silly, doesn't it?  By the way, I love your name.  I'm expecting a miracle also!!  Thanks to all who responded and helped me be a little less frightened.  Everyone here is in my thoughts and prayers!  Love, Kathy
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2009 12:36PM shadow38 wrote: Hi Girls! I know my case is unusual, but I wonder if anyone can help or perhaps knows someone who went thru this! I'm a Chemo-freak.  I didn't lose my hair, much to the shock of my Onc and everyone else.  I did weekly Taxol with dose dense Carboplatin added in every three weeks.  I'm also on Herceptin.  I completed Chemo on July 22nd.  The weird thing is, my hair was strong all thru Chemo although it didn't grow very much.  All the other hair on my body fell out on schedule.  I washed it as I normally did (everyday).  Finally, after the last Carbo treatment (2 weeks before Chemo ended), I started to shed a bit.  And I kept shedding right up until now.  My hair is thin, especially on the sides and pretty much looks awful.  Dull, broken, blah and thin.  I cut my hair really short again (did the same at the beginning of Chemo in anticipation of losing it).  I have tri colored hair at this point.  My roots are dark, my temples are gray and my ends are sorta blond. It's not thin enough to shave my head (crown and back are still full, sides are not).  Anyway, here I am, 6 weeks out of Chemo, looking like something the cat dragged thru a knot hole!  Also, I lost my eyelashes and eyebrows a couple of weeks after Chemo.  They're coming back but the hair on my head isn't.  It just keeps falling out, a few hairs at a time.  Also, the hair on my body is coming back with a vengence.  Anyone have any suggestions to spur the growth of hair on my head?  Has anyone gone thru something like this?  Also, what about dying what remains?  Do you think the rest of my hair will come out if I try it?  I know this must sound ridiculous to you girls, but I almost rather I'd lost my hair than look like this.  I feel really crappy about the way I look.  Any suggestions would be so appreciated.  Please help!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 03:11PM shadow38 wrote: Thanks so much for your input Koryn and soaplady.  I really, really appreciate it.  It seems no one here is in the same position as I am.  I realize many must feel I should be thankful that I still have some hair and have no sympathy for me.  That doesn't change the horrible way I feel though.  I'm not exactly thrilled with being the exception to the rule, especially considering the way I look right now. Thanx so much for the suggestions on color and the Biotin.  I'm absolutely going to give that a try!  A little color may make my hair look fuller.  Seeing my scalp on the sides of my head is not exactly attractive.    Who knows!!  Again, thank you so very much!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: shadow38 wrote: Hi Everyone: I'm wondering if any of you have experienced anything like this taking Neupogen shots after Chemo?  I just started taking Neupogen shots two weeks ago for 3 days after Chemo due to low Neutrophils. I hung in through 7 chemo's without needed the shots but after # 7 my Neutrophils finally crashed.  I take weekly Taxol and Herceptin with Carboplatin added in every 3 weeks.  Three days after taking the Neupogen shots I had a very strange side effect/reaction.  I had severe vomiting and diahrrea that last approx 8 - 10 hours.  This last time, chemo had to be postponed due to dehydration.  It can't be a side effect to chemo since it comes so far after chemo.  Not to be graphic, but the diahrrea lasted 8 hours and was constant.  I couldn't get up from the toilet.  The vomiting was just as bad.  I sat there with a bucket on my lap vomiting non stop until I was just wretching for hours at a time.  Compazine helped a little for the vomiting, but the Immodium they had me take for the diahrrea did very little.  It just kept coming.  I did some research on Neupogen.  It's made from the E-coli bacterium and one of the listed secondary side effects is vomiting and diahrrea, so in my mind it would make sense that I'm showing a sensitivity/allergic reaction to the E-coli bacterium.  Nothing else has changed in my tx.  These symptoms have only occurred once they added the Neupogen.  Unfortunately, I've had E-coli before and the symtoms I'm seeing are identical to what I experienced years ago when I had it.  Of course the Chemo Nurses are saying this is impossible since they've never seen it before.  Just because they haven't seen it, doesn't mean it doesn't happen as far as I'm concerned.  I hate the feeling of being blown off.  They're attitude is to treat the problem and not worry about what's causing it which seems a bit ridiculous to me.  They keep saying it's an "infection" but I have no fever and an infection doesn't reoccur exactly 7 days apart and get worse each time.  It also goes away exactly 8-10 hours after starting.  Thats not an infection.  It's a reaction to the newest thing added to my tx.  Does anyone have any thoughts on this or a similar experience?  I'm at my wits end.  The reaction is severe and very debilitating and the thought of going through it for another 3 cycles is upsetting me terribly!  PS:  Both times the Neupogen made my Neutrophil count to jump to over 5000 putting it in the mid range for normal.  Dx 3/10/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Strange Reaction to Neupogen - PLEASE HELP! shadow38 bluedasher

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2009 05:53PM shadow38 wrote: Hey konakat, They were concerned about dehydration.  I'll give them that atleast.  LOL!  When I go for my delayed chemo on Friday, I'll be bringing printouts from Neupogens manufacturer, the CDC, and Medline as well as the package insert that comes with the Neupogen that clearly states that vomiting and diahrrea are side effects.  I've spoken to my Onc and it was like pulling teeth to get her to see my point.  Because she has never seen this side effect, her stance was, at first, that it doesn't exist.  After hitting her with hard, cold facts and showing her that my problems only began exactly immediately after taking the Neupogen, she started to relent.  She backed down and said it was "possible".  She agreed to have me take less Neupogen after my upcoming treatment (its the triple treatment with the Carboplatin) and in my last 2 treatments, allow me to forego the Neupogen if my Neutrophil count is high enough.  Dear God....it was like pulling teeth.  It took everything I had to remain calm.  Thanks so much for your support.  We'll have to see what happens after my next go round.
Posts.Title: Strange Reaction to Neupogen - PLEASE HELP! shadow38 bluedasher

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2009 03:24PM shadow38 wrote: Thanks konakat and linda!  I'm getting on the phone directly with the covering Onc right now!  My Onc is on vacation.  The nurses continue to say my thoughts are "impossible" and "vomiting and diahrrea are not a side effect or allergic reaction to Neupogen".  I agree that taking a less aggressive stance on the Neupogen makes sense.  After all, I was the exception to the rule all thru tx.  I never lost my hair when they said I absolutely would.  My blood levels stayed high for longer than they thought and I never call and bother anyone.  I'm getting tired of their reaction.
Posts.Title: Strange Reaction to Neupogen - PLEASE HELP! shadow38 bluedasher

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 04:56PM shadow38 wrote: Hi Everyone: I just wanted to let you all know that I have an appointment with the breast surgeon tomorrow at 11:30 AM.  My husband will be coming with me.  The last couple of days have been a nightmare.  I can't eat, sleep or think of anything else.  I feel like my life is over and I don't have very long to live.  I shake all over, can't focus on anything else (not even a book or TV show), and the only thing I feel is abject TERROR.  I'm terrified it's spread to other parts of my body.  Please, please tell me this gets better.  Please tell me someday I will feel like myself again and that I'm not going to die.  Please tell me that somewhere in the future, I'll feel like I used to.  My son is only 19.  He's so scared.  I can see it on his face.  I can't believe I'm going thru this and putting my son and husband thru it.  Any help or support anybody can offer would be so appreciated. Love, Kathy
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 03:17PM - edited Mar 13, 2009 03:21PM by shadow38 Thank you so, so much, girls.  I can't even express how grateful I am for your support.  This forum has been a life saver.  Yesterday when I wrote, I was really on the edge.  Hyperventilating, crying non-stop and totally out of control.  Reading your words helped a bit to calm me and I will be eternally grateful for that.  You have my love, my respect and more gratitude than you can imagine. I went to the breast surgeon today and I think I got really good news.  Atleast it feels that way.  He did an ultrasound of both breasts and a full exam.  He found nothing to worry about in the left breast and no sign of any swelling under my arms.  He said the cyst was "incidental" and not caused by the cancer.  It was just one of those things that may have helped in that it MADE ME go for a mammogram.  He said he feels the actual tumor is "probably small".  When I asked about node involvement, he said "probably not".  He did find a tiny nodule in another spot on my right breast and said it was not a big deal.  In short, nothing is lighting up and screaming. I spoke to my girlfriend who was diagnosed the first time with IDC 17 years ago and had a reoccurance 2 years ago and she said a doctor rarely says anything like that unless he's pretty comfortable with his assessment.  I'm praying she's right.  I thought the tumor was HUGE based on the size of the cyst, but apparently the surgeon doesn't think so.  He does nothing but this so I would think he knows exactly what he's looking at.  Atleast I'm praying that's the case.  My girlfriend told me she was "elated" by what I was telling her.  That she felt it was really good news. They set me up for a breast MRI next Thursday (3/19) and are also in the process of setting an appointment with an oncologist he recommended and whom he works with extensively.  They will get me in after the MRI and before I go back to the breast surgeon on March 26th.  The doc said we'll discuss mastectomy vs lumpectomy at that time.  I guess he wants to confirm his suspicions with the MRI.  Does that sound right to you guys? I told the bs I was concerned that we weren't moving faster and he said not to be.   He said its usually approx a month between diagnosis and surgery.  What do you guys think of everything I've said?  I was expecting the worst, and right now this seems like a tiny bit of good news.  Do you agree?  Anything you can offer in the way of insight and experience would be so appreciated.  Love, Kathy PS.  They also offered me the BRAC Analysis test based on the fact that I'm adopted and have no genetic family history.  They said it might cost me as much as $3000.00 depending on whether my insurance was willing to work with the lab.  I took it.  Knowledge is power.  Did I do the right thing?
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 09:27PM - edited Mar 13, 2009 09:36PM by shadow38 Hi Tiffany, I just wanted to welcome you and send my very best your way.  I took the BRCA Analysis today so I can't offer any insight.  Just my best wishes, good thoughts and prayers.  Hi Sue, I am breathing a little easier.  For the first time in days I don't feel like I'm dying.  I was actually rational tonight, and believe me, if you would have seen me the past few days, you'd realize what a huge accomplishment that is for me.  I really felt as if the doctor would have said NOTHING if he wasn't fairly sure the tumor is small and there is probably no lymph node involvement.  I had envisioned this 3.5 cm monster in there.  I was sure I had let it go too long and it was going to be a death sentence.  When the bs said "this is not a death sentence"....well.....that's the last thing I heard.  I'm praying to God the bs is right and it's small with no node involvement.  I also asked about the possibility of it being Medullary Carcinoma vs IDC and he said he'd have no way of knowing until he saw the actual tumor.  I guess that makes sense.  He wasn't going in either direction on that.  The bs also checked with the lab to see if the ER/PR Her2 was back yet.  Not yet.       I have a silly question (although I'm sure you guys have heard every silly question there is).  What is considered a "small" tumor?  Is it 1 cm?  1.5 cm?  Does that effect the stage and the grade?  I am assuming the smaller the tumor the lower the stage.  Is that right?  Love, Kathy
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38

Posts.Content: shadow38 wrote: Hi Everyone, I was just diagnosed with Breast Cancer earlier this evening and I'm terrified, shocked and pretty much freaking out.  I'm 49, 3 years post menopause, have always been healthy, and don't know anything in terms of family history.  I'm adopted and no medical history is available.  I'm also sad to say that I hadn't had a mammogram in years.  I know.  I'm an idiot.  A little background:  I found a large lump on my right breast about a month ago.  Went for a mammogram and they also did an immediate sonogram.  I was told I was very, very lucky and it was only a cyst.  They suggested I have it aspirated.  The aspiration was done last Monday (3/2).  The report said they found "a few atypical cells" and a core biopsy was suggested.  The cyst refilled immediately after it was aspirated, by the way.  I was told "a cyst is just a cyst" and not to worry too much about it.  My GP said the chance of it being cancer was next to nothing.  Boy was he wrong.  The core biopsy was done this past Monday (3/9).  The radiologist told me the cyst was full of blood but seemed to make light of it.  I received the results from my GP today.  This is what the pathology report said: INVASIVE MAMMARY CARCINOMA, POORLY DIFFERENTIATED WITH MODERATE LYMPHOCYTIC REACTION. IN SITU COMPONENT IS NOT IDENTIFIED. NO DIAGNOSTIC EVIDENCE OF LYMPHOVASCULAR INVASION IS SEEN. FIBROADENOMATOID CHANGE. ACUTE HEMMORRHAGIC AND NECROTIZING TO CHRONIC FIBROZING INFLAMMATION, CONSISTENT WITH PREVIOUS ASPIRATION SITE. IMMUNOHISTOLCHEMICAL STUDIES FOR ER/PR AND HER 2 NEU PENDING:  A SEPARATE REPORT WILL FOLLOW. NOTE:  POSSIBLILITY OF MEDULLARY CARCINOMA OF BREAST SHOULD BE CONSIDERED ON EXCISIONAL SPECIMEN. I'm awaiting a referral from my GP for a Breast Surgeon.  Can anyone shed any light on this situation?  What should I expect?  How bad is this?  I so frightened and shocked!  Any help anyone can provide would be greatly appreciated.  Thank you. Kathy Dx 3/10/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 10:48PM - edited Mar 11, 2009 10:50PM by shadow38 Thanks to each and everyone of you for you kind and informative words.  I spoke to the breast surgeon I was recommended to at 10PM (I had left a message at his office never expecting a call back tonite).  In short, he said he'd see me by Friday, no matter what.  He said he'll make sure to fit me in.  He also said that my tumor is probably not 3.4 cm, but rather that was the size of the cyst.  That was encouraging.  Of course right now is just the total disbelief of the diagnosis and fear for my future.  Lets just say my head wasn't going good places today.  It was a really bad day.  Alot of crying.  I think reality is setting in.  GP gave me Xanax to sleep.  It definitely works.  It feels like sleep is the only respite from the fear....but I guess you guys have already been there.  Thank God I found this place when I did.  I have never seen so many caring, supportive, wonderful people gathered in one place.  God Bless each and every one of you you.  Everything scares me right now.  The possibility of node involvement.  The possiblility that they'll find something else in the MRI or other tests.  The pain.  That scares the hell out of me.  I'm a real barrel of laughs right now for my poor husband and 19 year old son, not to mention here.    I guess I have to start thinking about Mastectomy Vs. Lumpectomy and reconstruction soon as well.  God.....its all so much at once.  I'm looking for that sunnier place too, Linda and I believe if anyone can guide us there, it's our more "experienced sisters".  I asked my good friend who is a 14 year bs survivor until 2 years ago when she had another bout with IDC Stage IV and she assures me I WILL laugh again. Jill, Deana, Sue, Terry, Val and Linda....Thank you from the bottom of my heart.  I'll keep you posted on what the surgeon says and how things are progressing. Love, Kathy
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 11:53AM shadow38 wrote: Hi Carol, I'm so sorry to hear about your situation, but it seems we're both in the right place getting information from these amazing women.  It's definitely not easy gathering information, especially when you don't know what to look at  because you only have a partial diagnosis.  It's maddening.  I STILL don't know if I'm ER/PR negative or positive yet!  I thought by today, they'd have the results on that.  Yes....a month between biopsy and surgery seems about right.  My bs even told me that and said it wouldn't matter or advance the cancer.  Still....it's terrifying.  I just want it OUT!!  I imagine you feel the same way.  On an intellectual level, I know this is journey and I'll have all the information in time, but the waiting is torture.  I can't even think about tomorrow, let alone prepare for it.   Good luck to you with your surgery.  You'll be in my thoughts and prayers, Carol.  ______________________________________________________________  Dear Sue, Thank you AGAIN for the encouragement.  Knowing that you're out hiking a year out is so helpful.  As I said to Carol, I can't even think about tomorrow, let alone a year from now.  To know that SOMEDAY I'll be less terrified helps so much.  Right now, I can't see that from where I'm standing.  I guess I'm just a big baby.  I was able to eat a little more this weekend.  From diagnosis to this past Saturday (4 days) I lost 7 lbs which is alot for me.   I still can't sleep very much.  My internist put me on Ambien - 10mg and it's not doing a thing!  After taking it, I slept for about 2 hours and was wide awake again.  It was as if I hadn't taken anything.  The weekend was easier than today.  My husband was home from work, my brother and sister-in-law came to visit and offer encouragement, and my son was around.  Being Monday, my husband is at work and my son is at school today.  Being alone is horrible.  There's so much time to think. Have a wonderful time in Illinois!  You certainly deserve it!  Thank you again for being so encouraging and helpful.  You're a sweetheart, Sue.  I've posted a new topic with questions, by the way.  Perhaps someone has some insight or a story similar to mine to share.
Posts.Title: Help Interpreting Pathology Report shadow38 shadow38

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 07:06PM shadow38 wrote: First of all, CONGRATULATIONS on your clean margins and no chemo, Liz.  I'm really happy for you.  My margins weren't clean.  I had my re-excision on 9/3 after Chemo.  This time, I was free and clear of cancer.  YAY!!  I went for my initial set up today and it went well.  My tech was an absolute sweetheart and answered so many of my questions!!  First, they made the mold that will fit around my body to keep me in position during my treatments, then she did some markings with a permanent marker and took pictures, and finally, I had the CT Scan.  Piece of cake.  The whole thing took a half hour or so.  I go for my simulation Wednesday (9/30) and start Rads the next day (10/1).  I'm going at 10:30 every morning.  That seemed like a good time.  I'll be finished on November 12th.  I'm nervous.  It's the fear of the unknown.  I was told that after having gone thru Chemo, Rads would seem like a walk in the park.  I hope that's the case.  I couldn't stand it if it was anything like Chemo.  I felt like crap by the end of that and I'm just starting to feel better now.  Also hoping my skin holds up. I bought Dove body wash today and a big tube of Eucerin Calming Ointment.  I think I'm going to pickup some of the pure Aloe you girls have mentioned as well.  Can't hurt!! My very best to everyone as we continue this journey together!!
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 03:24PM - edited Sep 14, 2009 03:32PM by shadow38 Hi Girls, Thanks for starting this thread PauldingMom!  I'm joining you girls!  I was diagnosed on March 10th, had a lumpectomy with 2 dirty margins on April 13th, did Chemo after surgery (finished Chemo 7/22 - Taxol, Carboplatin and of course, Herceptin which will continue for a year), saw my Rad Onc in late August,  and had a re-excision on September 3rd.  I had clear margins and no sign of cancer (Thank God!!).  I'm going for my CAT scan on September 24th with Rads scheduled to begin the first week in October.  They wanted to wait until a month after surgery.  Thus far, I've been given samples of Eucerin and was told to start using it right after my stitches were removed to prepare myself.  I'm nervous, but not as frightened as I was before Chemo.  After going through and surviving that, I think I can deal with anything although the idea of my skin breaking down is pretty intimidating!   I'm feeling much better after my Chemo side effects.  The fatigue and pain was crushing!!  It's a bit depressing knowing that the fatigue may come back, but I'm hoping it's not nearly as bad as the fatigue I suffered during Chemo.  At one point, I was sleeping 14-16 hours a day!!  It can't be that bad, can it?  I guess I'm about to find out!!  Good luck to all my October Rad sisters.  May we experience as few side effects as possible! Edited to Add:  I'm having 30 treatments.  25 Regular and 5 Boosts.  My surgeon suggested a Mammosite but unfortunately, my breasts are too dense.  Oh Well!!
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 12:17PM - edited Oct 11, 2009 12:23PM by shadow38 Hi October Girls !! Well, I started Rads on October 1st.  My final day is November 12th.  On the good side, I'm in and out of the Rads center in 20 minutes.  They're waiting for me when I arrive (at 10:30 AM) and take me right in.  They're incredibly efficient and the 3 techs who do the treatment everyday are super sweet.  I have 2 young women and 1 young man (they can't be older than 26 or 27).  I have to admit, the young guy freaked me out at first, but he did a really great job of making me feel comfortable.  On the down side, I started feeling very tired after 8 treatments.  Not the usual tired, but more like a lessened version of the fatigue you experience with Chemo (had 3 months of TCH - finished 7/22).  I'm also experiencing nipple tenderness and those pains in the breast so many are describing.  Hate to say this, but reading that others are having these pains actually encouraged me (sorry about that!!).  My skin is looking fine so far, but I have to admit that the fatigue is upsetting me.  After feeling like crap for months, I was finally starting to feel more like me when I started Rads.  I hadn't counted on the fatigue hitting this quickly.  I also didn't count on the pain in my breast and the nipple discomfort.  No one warned me about that and to be honest, it scared the bejesus out of me.  For some odd reason, I felt stronger emotionally during Chemo and my surgeries than I do now.  I don't know what it is.  Maybe after 7 months of doing this whole cancer thing, I'm just emotionally drained or maybe the reality and the "new normal" is actually hitting me.  Who knows.  All I know is I'm jumpier than I was and I have less patience for those around me.  I guess frustration would be the best description of how I'm feeling.  Like I just want this to be OVER so I can deal with the future.  Anyone else experiencing that ?  Also, I'm using Eucerin Calming Cream on the entire area from my collarbone down to about 3 inches below my breast and from between the girls where my tattoo is to around to my back where my other tattoo is located.  I'm using a generous amount twice a day.....right after treatment and before I go to bed.  I'm also using Eucerin Oil bodywash and their itch cream (which I haven't needed yet).  It's working very well !!  I have the softest right boob on the planet and so far, my skin is not breaking down !!  LOL!!  I also have Aquafor in case I need it.  The Eucerin Calming Cream is not as greasy as the Aquafor and doesn't stain my clothing or my bra.  I also try to go without my bra (which is a regular non-underwire) as much as I can.  I think I'll pickup some Pure Aloe Gel as well.  Can't hurt !!  My best wishes to all the brave October Gals.  Lotsa love and hang in there !!
Posts.Title: October Rads. 2009 PauldingMom linn56
